Award.AwardTitle: Full-Scale Development Project: Marcellus Matters: Engaging Adults in Science and Energy (EASE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Full-Scale Informal Science Education award focuses on the physical and social science surrounding the extraction of natural gas from the Marcellus shale formation beneath the surface in north central and western Pennsylvania. The project targets the adult residents of the impacted or soon-to-be-impacted areas of Pennsylvania. This is a complex project involving the disciplines of geology, engineering, chemistry, social science, performance, and land management. Further, the project team includes a mix of physical scientists, educators, theater arts faculty, social scientists and engineers from Pennsylvania State University, the Pennsylvania State Cooperative Extension Service, and Juniata College.

The project addresses several potential barriers to communication of science to the public. The proposal team provides four entry points for citizens of rural Pennsylvania to engage in learning about energy, its needs in the Nation, the economics behind these needs, the geology of the shale deposit and how to have productive discussions and make decisions using science-based evidence. The project will engage a multitude of communication mechanisms such as forums, community meetings, theater performances, data centers, blogs and workshops. The Pennsylvania State Extension will play a central role in working at the local level.

The project is a complex effort wherein the residents of north central and western Pennsylvania will learn about the science and policies of natural gas extraction and how to derive and use scientific information for decision making. The proposal team will learn how to work and communicate with rural citizens. Further, the team will derive a variety of models from these activities that are likely to be adaptable for use in other areas of the Nation that have natural gas deposits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Marcellus Matters : Engaging Adults in Science and Energy (EASE) was a multidisciplinary initiative that provided adults in rural Pennsylvania with opportunities to increase their knowledge of science and energy systems and engage in scientific inquiry and investigation through the lens of natural gas development.

Central to the EASE project was the Marcellus Community Scientist (MCS) program. Loosely modeled after successful Master Gardener and Master Naturalist programs, our program used a “train-the-trainer” approach in which we offered non-credit, in-depth programming to community members who, after the training, were expected to “transfer” that knowledge to their communities through presentations to and conversations with community members “Graduates” of our program are known as sources of reliable and unbiased information. Our program also trained a number of community-based citizen scientists in scientific inquiry and investigation through the Marcellus Community Network (MCN), a technology-enabled citizen-science program. Our MCN website was designed for adult learners to share their observations, data and questions about environmental changes linked to Marcellus Shale development through social networking tools such as forums, blogs and knowledge bases. For training, we focused on searching for and identifying “legacy wells,” essentially older abandoned (orphaned) oil and gas wells in Pennsylvania that may not have been properly cased or plugged and could be a source of pollutants to groundwater and the atmosphere. Natural gas pipeline development became an additional focus.

We also developed theatre as a vehicle for highlighting issues and encouraging conversations. The Marcellus Community Conversations (MCC) engaged adult residents, landowners, and local decision makers in active-learning, knowledge-generating performances made collectively with those most impacted by shale gas development. The philosophy of our community-based performances was a “community constituted by virtue of a shared primary identity,”—in this instance, a shared identity based in both place and the common resource of shale gas. These performances engaged the spectators in the performance itself as a way of making meaning. We found this to be a unique and effective way to achieve good debate, to engage community participants in discussion through the exchange of ideas, argument and counterargument, in an effort to further the education of all.

 

The Marcellus EASE project also offered Marcellus By Design (MBD), a suite of in-person experiences and online resources intended to help participants identify solutions to community planning challenges arising from local shale gas development including a series of environmental planning workshops to engage residents in deliberative discussions on Marcellus Shale environmental issues within their region. Drawing on the principles of landscape architecture, community-planning workshops involved game elements designed to highlight the complexity of planning for land use, as well as community-specific ideas for managing the effects of shale gas development. In addition, the team developed a robust web presence in order to sustain these community supports beyond the funded grant. The central goal of Marcellus By Design was to support community members by offering tools to engage in the planning discussions that affect their lives.

As a final legacy product, our Marcellus EASE team has developed an online course that will open in Fall, 2017. The Marcellus Community Science course is an Open Education Resource (OER). OER means that the course content is available for reuse by teachers and learners worldwide who do not intend to apply for admission, register for classes, or pursue a certificate or degree at Penn State. The resources are freely available for non-commercial use under a Creative Commons license. This course makes the Community Science Volunteer educational modules accessible to others. The modules are:  The Process of Science, Energy Choices for PA and the US, Constructive Conversations, Geology and Seismic Testing, Shale Development Engineering, Understanding Pipeline Regulation and Construction, Land Use Planning and Design, Water Quality, Community and Economic Impacts, and Orphan and Abandoned Wells.

In summary, the Marcellus Matters: Engaging Adults in Science and Energy (EASE) project engaged adult residents, landowners and local decision makers in rural Pennsylvania to further their understanding of science, engineering, and energy through the lens of the Marcellus Shale; to build a shared knowledge base on science and energy that empowers rural communities to make decisions and manage change; and to teach effective strategies for science-informed community deliberations of complex environmental issues.
